node.title: Tairāwhiti state of emergency lifted after flooding
node.description: The state of emergency in Tairāwhiti has this afternoon been lifted after three days of torrential rain.

node.title: Fire in historic Christchurch building leads to evacuations
node.description: A derelict building in Christchurch caught fire for the second time in three years this morning - forcing some to evacuate their homes.

node.title: DOC investigating death of 11 fur seals in Kaikōura
node.description: The deaths of eleven fur seals in Kaikōura are being treated as suspicious.

node.title: Israel Moves to Silence the Stalwarts of Palestinian Civil Society
node.description: These human rights activists are not terrorists.

node.title: A US nuclear-powered attack submarine hit something underwater – now its two senior officers have been fired
node.description: The USS Connecticut, a nuclear-powered fast-attack submarine, was reported to have struck an "object" underwater in early October under the busy shipping lanes of the South China Sea.

node.title: NT government pulls vaccination stats from website, admits remote region data was inflated
node.description: The Northern Territory government removes regional vaccine data from its website after being asked why there was a discrepancy of more than 50 per cent compared to the federal government's figures.

node.title: Jordan De Goey to 'vigorously defend himself' after being charged in the US
node.description: The Collingwood AFL player releases a statement via his lawyer after being charged in the United States last weekend.

node.title: New Antarctica NZ base to be built in Timaru
node.description: The entire base will be built at Timaru's port over a six-year period and will then shipped to Antarctica in eight modules on a massive ship.

node.title: Johnson & Johnson loses bid to take pelvic mesh appeal to High Court
node.description: Pharmaceutical giant Johnson & Johnson has its bid for an appeal to a Federal Court ruling thrown out of the High Court.

node.title: Deputy PM on time slots for Christmas travel: 'It wouldn't be very practical'
node.description: Aucklanders will probably have a better option than allocated time to leave the region over the holidays, the deputy prime minister says. Audio

node.title: What Does War Feel Like to a Child?
node.description: “How War Changed Rondo,” a picture book by the Ukrainian artists Romana Romanyshyn and Andriy Lesiv, captures the unrelenting destructiveness of wartime as a young person experiences it.

node.title: Steve Sheinkin’s Explosive Sequel to ‘Bomb’
node.description: “Fallout: Spies, Superbombs, and the Ultimate Cold War Showdown” offers a whirlwind account of events leading up to the Cuban missile crisis.

node.title: The Curious Tale of Mr. Kale
node.description: He was everything I expected and wanted. So why hasn’t he returned to Whole Foods?

node.title: Your Friday Briefing
node.description: A Covid hot spot in Italy.

node.title: Atlanta Had to Celebrate Its Title Without Its Architect
node.description: Home after testing positive for the coronavirus, Alex Anthopoulos missed the party that wouldn’t have been possible without his brilliant deadline maneuvers.

node.title: House with window to the stars wins top architectural prize
node.description: An accessible custom-designed home in the NSW Blue Mountains, whose roof opens to a view of the milky way, wins a top prize as one of the nation's best designed homes — the Robin Boyd Award for Residential Architecture.

node.title: NASA unveils asteroid-fighting spacecraft as it prepares for Armageddon-style mission test
node.description: The spacecraft will be launched later this month on a test mission to determine whether crashing into an asteroid can change its trajectory.

node.title: ABC announces more jobs, funding for regional and rural journalism
node.description: Managing director David Anderson says the cash injection will allow bureaus to deliver more local content across platforms.

node.title: Police charge two men over Mangere drive-by shooting
node.description: Police say eight search warrants were executed across two Auckland suburbs this morning to locate two men who allegedly shot at an innocent family's home.

node.title: New Antarctica NZ base to be build in Timaru
node.description: The entire base will be built at Timaru's port over a six-year period and will then shipped to Antarctica in eight modules on a massive ship.

node.title: Black Caps to take five spinners on tour of India
node.description: Experienced spin trio Ajaz Patel, Will Somerville and Mitchell Santner will be joined by Rachin Ravindra and Glenn Phillips on the Black Caps tour of India.

node.title: Protesting in a pandemic: NZ's balancing act between a long tradition of protests and Covid rules
node.description: As Delta infections rise and several professions now face mandatory vaccination as part of the drive to get to 90 percent vaccination rates, protests will likely expand.

node.title: Man Unable To Leave Canada After National Postal Service Loses Passport
node.description: The man may have to spend $600 CAD to get a new passport.

node.title: CCTV vital as Cleo Smith investigators shift focus to movements of her alleged abductor
node.description: As the investigation into the disappearance of Cleo Smith enters its third week, officers will be turning their attention to the activity of the man accused of taking her.
